title: I Tried a Day Off From MS and Almost Wound Up in the Hospital

content: Do you ever really want to do something, but you know your multiple sclerosis (MS) will make it hard? But you really want to do it, or maybe you feel you have to, so you try? I tried that last week and it didn’t go well at all.

I should have known better, but I sort of went into MS denial. I wanted to see my old girlfriend Jane, whom I hadn’t seen in several months. We used to co-lead an MS support group together, but 5 years ago, she moved to assisted living across the Bay. COVID basically shut down the support group we led, and our visits slowed to like once every 3 months. I missed her.

On Thursday, Jane invited me to come to the Cherry Festival in San Leandro where she lives. There would be four blocks of music, crafts, vendors, and street food, just the kind of event I like, and I had baked some special brownies for her.

We used to co-lead an MS support group together, but 5 years ago, she moved to assisted living across the Bay. COVID basically shut down the support group we led, and our visits slowed to like once every 3 months. I missed her.

On Thursday, Jane invited me to come to the Cherry Festival in San Leandro where she lives. There would be four blocks of music, crafts, vendors, and street food, just the kind of event I like, and I had baked some special brownies for her.

content: So I said yes, I would come. Her place is about 70 minutes from mine by bus and BART train, but I can do that trip. I set out about 11 a.m. and got to San Leandro a bit after 12:30 p.m.

As soon as I got off BART and on to the street, I knew there would be a problem with heat. Like a lot of people with MS, I don’t tolerate heat well. My muscles get weaker, and my mind gets fuzzier. I hadn’t checked the weather before I left, but even if I had, I probably would have come, because I had decided MS wasn’t going to rule me for this one day.

According to weather.com, the temperature was 75 degrees. That’s warmer than I like but not too warm. The problem was the sun. It was noon time in mid-June, and the sun was almost directly overhead, so there was no shade. It felt a lot hotter than 75.

It took me 20 minutes to find Jane in the crowd. The loud music made it hard to hear on the phone, and Jane doesn’t talk so well since her stroke, so we couldn’t hear each other. It was like the days before cellphones, but finally we found each other.

content: I was already warm, but my strength still felt normal, so we set off to see the festival. On most days, I would have said “MS, you win.” I should have given Jane a hug and the brownies and told her I was sorry, but I couldn’t stay. I should have headed right back to BART and returned to the cool safety of San Francisco.

But I didn’t want to disappoint her, and I did want to spend time with her, because I rarely do. So we started exploring. It wasn’t a good match. For one thing, Jane is not heat sensitive the way I am. She preferred being in the sun, while I was searching desperately for any little shade I could find, like under an awning. She would leave me there and go off to see the fair booths. So we didn’t get to visit much.

I started noticing that my hands were getting weaker and it was getting harder to sit up straight in my scooter. I realized I needed to leave soon, but we had planned to have lunch. The problem was most of the food trucks and booths had long lines, so by the time I got my sandwich, I was almost too weak to unwrap it and eat it.

content: At that point, I finally gave up and said, “I have to go now.” Jane was disappointed but said she would accompany me back to BART, which was about three blocks away. By then I had gotten so weak that my right hand would not stay on the scooter handlebars and I had to use two hands to operate it. I was getting anxious about being able to make it home. I tried pouring water from my bottle over my head and back, and it helped a little, but not much.

When we got to the station, the overhead platform created some nice, relatively cool shade, and I could have stayed there and cooled a little. Because Jane was worried about me, she was still with me, but she wanted to stay warm, so she was sitting far away in the sun. I didn’t want to make her wait, and I wanted to get home, so I decided to keep scooting to the train.

content: What I didn’t know, because it’s never happened before, is that MS in the heat could sap my core strength so badly. When I got to the fare gate, I turned back to say goodbye to Jane, and my body just wilted. I slid out of the scooter and landed on the floor and couldn’t get up.

I remember worrying that my scooter was blocking the accessible gate. I was happy to lie on the cool floor and rest my head on the tiles. Nothing hurt, and a station agent came and asked if I needed help. I said yes, and they called an ambulance. A few minutes later, three strong-looking young men came and checked me out.

They wanted to take me to a hospital, but I was sure I hadn’t been injured and asked if they would just put me back in the scooter, because I still felt weak. They lifted me in and one of them got me a plastic water bottle since mine was empty, and they said goodbye.

content: I still wasn’t thinking clearly, but it was much cooler on the elevated platform and I started to feel better. I was even able to eat some of my sandwich. When I finally got home. I slept for nearly 3 hours. Then I was better and so glad and lucky not to have been seriously injured in the fall.

Of course Jane was really upset, and I don’t know what the EMT services will wind up costing me. But I re-learned a lesson I used to know: I can’t pretend I don’t have MS for a day. It doesn’t go away. If I really want to do something hard, I can accept that there may be a price, like feeling knocked out for a day. That’s OK. But don’t risk having it turn into an ordeal , defined by the Oxford dictionary as “a painful or horrible experience, especially a protracted or dangerous one.”

The other lesson I’m still learning is not to put other people’s concerns ahead of my own needs. Why was I so worried about disappointing my friend? I have no way of knowing how disappointed she would be, and avoiding it was not worth endangering my body. I put myself through an ordeal, and ordeals are not worth it. I promise I will stay out of the heat whenever I possibly can from now on. MS doesn’t take a day off.
